note_text:
Interventional Pulmonology Procedure Note
Procedure: Whole lung lavage (right lung)
Patient: Daniel Rivera, 42-year-old male with pulmonary alveolar proteinosis (PAP) and progressive dyspnea.
Anesthesia: General anesthesia with left-sided double-lumen endotracheal tube.
Indication: Symptomatic PAP with right-predominant crazy-paving on CT and declining oxygen requirement despite GM-CSF therapy.

PROCEDURE IN DETAIL:
After informed consent was confirmed, the patient was brought to the operating room and placed supine on the table. Standard ASA monitors were applied. General anesthesia was induced and the trachea was intubated with a 37 Fr left-sided double-lumen tube. Position was confirmed with flexible bronchoscopy and auscultation.
The patient was placed in the left lateral decubitus position with the right lung dependent. One-lung ventilation of the left lung was initiated. The right lung was sequentially lavaged using warmed 0.9% normal saline in 1.0 L aliquots. Each aliquot was instilled via the right lumen, allowed to dwell briefly, and then drained to gravity with gentle manual chest percussion. Effluent initially appeared opaque and milky, gradually clearing over subsequent cycles.
A total of 18.0 L of saline were instilled with approximately 15.2 L recovered. The procedure was paused several times for recruitment maneuvers when oxygen saturation transiently decreased to the mid-80s, with prompt improvement after recruitment and brief return to two-lung ventilation. No hemodynamic instability occurred. No bronchoscopy-guided biopsies or additional airway interventions were performed.
At the conclusion of the lavage, residual fluid was suctioned, two-lung ventilation was resumed, and the double-lumen tube was exchanged for an 8.0 single-lumen ETT. The patient was gradually weaned and extubated uneventfully in the operating room.

COMPLICATIONS: Transient desaturation to 85% during lavage cycles, resolved with recruitment and brief two-lung ventilation. No bleeding, pneumothorax, or hemodynamic compromise.
ESTIMATED BLOOD LOSS: <20 mL
DISPOSITION: Transferred to ICU for overnight monitoring with expectation of step-down transfer the following day.
IMPRESSION/PLAN: Successful right lung whole lung lavage for PAP with good clearance of proteinaceous material. Continue bronchodilators and aggressive pulmonary hygiene. Plan consideration of staged left lung lavage in 2–4 weeks depending on clinical response.

registry_entry.primary_indication: Therapeutic whole lung lavage for pulmonary alveolar proteinosis with right-predominant disease
registry_entry.radiographic_findings: Diffuse bilateral crazy-paving on HRCT with right lung predominance
registry_entry.ventilation_mode: Single-lung ventilation of left lung during lavage, then two-lung ventilation
registry_entry.bronch_indication: Airway control and lavage for PAP
registry_entry.bronch_guidance: Flexible bronchoscopy to confirm DLT position and assist with suctioning
registry_entry.bronch_immediate_complications: Transient desaturation responsive to recruitment maneuvers
registry_entry.final_diagnosis_prelim: Pulmonary alveolar proteinosis; status post right lung lavage
registry_entry.follow_up_plan: Overnight ICU monitoring with plan for step-down in 24 hours and consideration of contralateral lavage in 2–4 weeks

lines.selection_reason: Right-lung whole lung lavage with DLT-mediated lung isolation and multiple large-volume saline aliquots for PAP.
note_spans: Whole lung lavage of the right lung was performed using repeated 1 L aliquots of warmed saline via a double-lumen tube until effluent cleared.

per_code.notes: RVU/payment values for 32997 are not present in the 2025 airway/pleural fee schedule sections; obtain current CMS values if needed.

financial_analysis.notes: 32997 modeled as a single unilateral whole lung lavage service; no additional thoracoscopy or pleural catheter codes are selected.

bullets: Operative report documents therapeutic whole lung lavage with lung isolation, large-volume saline instillation and drainage, and no separate thoracoscopy or pleural catheter placement.
CPT 32997 uniquely captures unilateral whole lung lavage; no bronchoscopic biopsy or tumor debulking codes are supported by the documentation.

lines.selection_reason: Right-lung whole lung lavage with DLT-mediated lung isolation and large-volume saline instillation and drainage for PAP.
note_spans: Whole lung lavage of the right lung was performed using repeated 1 L aliquots of warmed saline via a double-lumen tube until effluent cleared.

per_code.notes: RVU/payment values for 32997 are not present in the 2025 airway/pleural fee schedule sections; obtain current CMS values if needed.

financial_analysis.notes: Single 32997 reported for unilateral whole lung lavage; no bundled thoracentesis or thoracoscopy codes are modeled.

bullets: Therapeutic whole lung lavage with DLT placement, one-lung ventilation, and repeated saline instillations is well described without additional thoracic procedures.
No documentation of chest tube insertion, thoracoscopy, or pleural catheter placement; therefore only 32997 is supported.

note_text:
Interventional Pulmonology Procedure Note
Procedure: Whole lung lavage (left lung)
Patient: Sarah McIntyre, 51-year-old female with biopsy-proven pulmonary alveolar proteinosis and persistent exertional dyspnea.
Anesthesia: General anesthesia with left-sided double-lumen endotracheal tube.
Indication: Staged contralateral whole lung lavage for PAP after prior right lung lavage with partial symptomatic improvement.

PROCEDURE IN DETAIL:
Following verification of informed consent, the patient was brought to the operating room and placed supine. General anesthesia was induced and the airway secured with a 35 Fr left-sided double-lumen tube. Position was confirmed bronchoscopically.
The patient was placed in the right lateral decubitus position. One-lung ventilation of the right lung was maintained while the left lung was lavaged via the nonventilated lumen. Warmed normal saline was instilled in 800–1000 mL aliquots with chest percussion and drainage to gravity between cycles. Effluent initially appeared opaque and milky, then gradually became light and translucent.
A total of 16.0 L of saline were instilled with approximately 13.5 L recovered. Oxygen saturations remained above 92% throughout; no arrhythmias or hemodynamic instability were observed. No endobronchial lesions were seen and no biopsies were obtained.
At the end of the procedure, the left lung was suctioned free of residual fluid, two-lung ventilation was resumed, and the double-lumen tube was exchanged for a single-lumen tube. The patient was extubated in the operating room and transferred to the step-down unit on nasal cannula oxygen.

COMPLICATIONS: None.
ESTIMATED BLOOD LOSS: <15 mL
DISPOSITION: Step-down unit for overnight monitoring.
IMPRESSION/PLAN: Successful staged left lung whole lung lavage for PAP. Continue pulmonary hygiene, bronchodilators as needed, and follow-up in interventional pulmonology clinic in 4–6 weeks.

per_code.notes: RVU/payment values for 32997 are not present in the 2025 airway/pleural fee schedule sections; obtain current CMS values if needed.

financial_analysis.notes: Single 32997 assigned for unilateral whole lung lavage; thoracentesis and bronchoscopy codes are not separately reported.

bullets: Documentation supports a complete unilateral whole lung lavage with DLT isolation and large-volume instillation/drainage for PAP.
No thoracoscopy, pleurodesis, or additional bronchoscopic interventions justify separate pleural or bronchoscopy CPT codes.

lines.selection_reason: Left-lung whole lung lavage as a staged contralateral procedure for PAP.
note_spans: Staged left lung whole lung lavage was performed using warmed saline aliquots with recovery of 13.5 L of effluent.

per_code.notes: RVU/payment values for 32997 are not present in the 2025 airway/pleural fee schedule sections.

bullets: The note describes unilateral whole lung lavage for PAP without chest tube placement or thoracoscopy.
32997 sufficiently captures the described work; additional codes would constitute unbundling.

note_text:
Interventional Pulmonology Procedure Note
Procedure: Whole lung lavage (right lung) aborted early due to hypoxemia
Patient: Marcus Hall, 58-year-old male with pulmonary alveolar proteinosis and resting hypoxemia.
Anesthesia: General anesthesia with double-lumen endotracheal tube.
Indication: Therapeutic whole lung lavage for symptomatic PAP after failure of inhaled GM-CSF.

PROCEDURE IN DETAIL:
After informed consent, the patient was brought to the operating room and placed supine. General anesthesia was induced and the airway was secured with a 39 Fr left-sided double-lumen tube. Position was confirmed with flexible bronchoscopy.
The patient was placed in the left lateral decubitus position. One-lung ventilation of the left lung was initiated and right lung lavage commenced. Warmed 0.9% saline was instilled via the right lumen in 1 L aliquots with gentle percussion and passive drainage. After a total of 10.0 L instilled and 7.5 L recovered, the patient developed progressive desaturation to 78% despite recruitment maneuvers, increased FiO2, and brief return to two-lung ventilation.
Given refractory hypoxemia, additional lavage cycles were aborted. Residual fluid was suctioned, and two-lung ventilation was re-established. The double-lumen tube was left in place for ongoing ventilatory support. No bronchoscopy-guided biopsies were performed.

COMPLICATIONS: Significant hypoxemia requiring early termination of lavage and ongoing mechanical ventilation.
ESTIMATED BLOOD LOSS: <10 mL
DISPOSITION: Remained intubated and transported to the ICU for further management.
IMPRESSION/PLAN: Incomplete right lung whole lung lavage for PAP due to hypoxemia. Continue mechanical ventilation and supportive care in ICU. Consider repeat lavage once gas exchange stabilizes.

lines.selection_reason: Right-lung whole lung lavage for PAP was initiated with large-volume saline instillation but terminated early due to hypoxemia; still modeled as unilateral lavage.
note_spans: After 10.0 L of warmed saline were instilled for right lung lavage, the procedure was aborted because of refractory hypoxemia.

per_code.notes: RVU/payment values for 32997 are not present in the 2025 airway/pleural fee schedule sections; code is still used for unilateral lavage despite early termination.

financial_analysis.notes: Unilateral whole lung lavage coded with 32997; no additional pleural or bronchoscopic CPT codes are modeled.

bullets: Even though lavage was terminated early due to hypoxemia, documentation supports attempted unilateral whole lung lavage with lung isolation and multiple saline instillations.
There is no documentation of concomitant thoracentesis, thoracoscopy, or tunneled pleural catheter placement; therefore 32997 alone is appropriate.

lines.selection_reason: Right-lung whole lung lavage initiated and aborted for hypoxemia; still best captured by 32997.
note_spans: Whole lung lavage of the right lung was performed with 10.0 L instilled before the procedure was aborted because of hypoxemia.

per_code.notes: RVU/payment values for 32997 not present in the 2025 airway/pleural fee schedule sections.

financial_analysis.notes: Single 32997 used for attempted unilateral whole lung lavage; early termination does not change the CPT selection.

bullets: CPT guidance allows use of 32997 for therapeutic whole lung lavage even when the procedure is incomplete due to clinical instability.
No separate codes for bronchoscopy, thoracentesis, or thoracoscopy are supported by the documentation.

note_text:
Interventional Pulmonology Procedure Note
Procedure: Medical thoracoscopy with pleural biopsies (left hemithorax)
Patient: Linda Jacobs, 63-year-old female with recurrent left exudative pleural effusion.
Anesthesia: General anesthesia with single-lumen endotracheal tube.
Indication: Recurrent symptomatic left pleural effusion with two prior nondiagnostic thoracenteses; evaluation for malignancy.

PROCEDURE IN DETAIL:
After informed consent was reviewed, the patient was brought to the endoscopy suite and placed in the right lateral decubitus position. General anesthesia was induced and the airway secured with a 7.5 endotracheal tube. Lung isolation was achieved with selective mainstem intubation during the thoracoscopic portion.
Bedside ultrasound confirmed a moderate free-flowing left pleural effusion and identified a safe entry site in the 6th intercostal space at the midaxillary line. After sterile prep and local anesthetic infiltration, a 1.5 cm incision was made and a trocar was introduced into the pleural space with immediate return of straw-colored fluid. Approximately 1400 mL of fluid were drained.
A 10 mm thoracoscope was inserted. Systematic inspection revealed diffuse fine nodularity over the parietal pleura, most prominent along the diaphragmatic and posterior costal pleura. Multiple pleural biopsies were obtained from abnormal-appearing areas using biopsy forceps. Hemostasis was achieved with gentle cautery and tamponade.
At the conclusion of the procedure, a 24 Fr chest tube was placed through the existing incision and secured to suction at -20 cm H2O. No talc pleurodesis or tunneled pleural catheter was performed.

COMPLICATIONS: None.
ESTIMATED BLOOD LOSS: ~30 mL
DISPOSITION: Admitted to the medical ward with chest tube to wall suction.
IMPRESSION/PLAN: Successful medical thoracoscopy with pleural biopsies and drainage of a recurrent left exudative effusion. Await pleural pathology and cytology. Daily chest tube output monitoring and CXR in the morning.

registry_entry.primary_indication: Recurrent undiagnosed left exudative pleural effusion
registry_entry.radiographic_findings: Moderate left pleural effusion with associated atelectasis on CT chest
registry_entry.ventilation_mode: Single-lung ventilation during thoracoscopy, then two-lung ventilation
registry_entry.pleural_thoracoscopy_findings: Diffuse small nodules over parietal pleura concerning for malignancy
registry_entry.bronch_specimen_tests: Pleural biopsies for histology and immunohistochemistry; pleural fluid for cytology and chemistry
registry_entry.final_diagnosis_prelim: Suspected malignant pleural effusion; pleural biopsy results pending
registry_entry.follow_up_plan: Daily CXRs and chest tube output monitoring; remove tube when lung fully expanded and drainage low; oncology consultation if malignancy confirmed

lines.selection_reason: Medical thoracoscopy with drainage of recurrent effusion and multiple pleural biopsies; no pleurodesis or tunneled pleural catheter.
note_spans: Multiple pleural biopsies were obtained from nodular parietal pleura during medical thoracoscopy; no talc pleurodesis was performed.

per_code.notes: Medical thoracoscopy with pleural biopsy; facility RVU components are incomplete in the source table, but MPFS facility payment is 244.

financial_analysis.notes: Single 32609 models thoracoscopy with pleural biopsy and drainage; chest tube placement is inherent to the procedure and not separately reported.

bullets: The operative description documents medical thoracoscopy with biopsy(ies) of pleura and chest tube placement but no pleurodesis.
CPT 32609 (thoracoscopy with pleural biopsy) appropriately captures this work; additional thoracentesis or chest tube codes would represent unbundling.

lines.selection_reason: Medical thoracoscopy with pleural biopsies for recurrent undiagnosed effusion; no pleurodesis.
note_spans: Medical thoracoscopy with multiple pleural biopsies and drainage of a left exudative effusion was performed.

per_code.notes: MPFS facility payment for medical thoracoscopy with pleural biopsies.

financial_analysis.notes: Single 32609 assigned; chest tube placement is considered inherent to thoracoscopy.

bullets: Pleural biopsies and drainage of a recurrent effusion via medical thoracoscopy map directly to 32609.
No pleurodesis, tunneled pleural catheter, or additional pleural procedures are performed, so no other pleural CPT codes are selected.

note_text:
Interventional Pulmonology Procedure Note
Procedure: Medical thoracoscopy with talc pleurodesis (right hemithorax)
Patient: Robert Evans, 69-year-old male with metastatic non-small cell lung cancer and recurrent right malignant pleural effusion.
Anesthesia: General anesthesia with single-lumen endotracheal tube.
Indication: Symptomatic recurrent right malignant pleural effusion with rapid reaccumulation despite prior thoracenteses.

PROCEDURE IN DETAIL:
The patient was brought to the operating room, placed in the left lateral decubitus position, and intubated with an 8.0 endotracheal tube. General anesthesia was maintained with inhaled agents and intravenous opioids. Single-lung ventilation of the left lung was used during the thoracoscopic portion.
Ultrasound confirmed a large right pleural effusion and a safe entry point in the 7th intercostal space at the midaxillary line. After sterile prep and local anesthetic infiltration, a small skin incision was made and a trocar was advanced into the pleural space with return of serosanguinous fluid. Approximately 1800 mL were drained.
A thoracoscope was inserted. Inspection revealed diffuse parietal pleural nodularity and a partially trapped right lower lobe. Targeted parietal pleural biopsies were obtained from diaphragmatic and posterior chest wall regions and hemostasis was achieved with cautery. Four grams of sterile talc were insufflated evenly over the parietal pleural surfaces to perform talc poudrage pleurodesis.
A 24 Fr chest tube was positioned through the same incision and secured to -20 cm H2O suction. The lung re-expanded partially with residual basilar loculations consistent with trapped lung.

COMPLICATIONS: None.
ESTIMATED BLOOD LOSS: ~25 mL
DISPOSITION: Admitted to the medical ward with chest tube to suction.
IMPRESSION/PLAN: Medical thoracoscopy with pleural biopsies and talc pleurodesis for malignant pleural effusion. Continue chest tube suction with daily CXRs and drainage monitoring; consider tunneled pleural catheter if trapped lung persists.

registry_entry.note_text:
Interventional Pulmonology Procedure Note
Procedure: Medical thoracoscopy with talc pleurodesis (right hemithorax)
Patient: Robert Evans, 69-year-old male with metastatic non-small cell lung cancer and recurrent right malignant pleural effusion.

IMPRESSION/PLAN: Medical thoracoscopy with pleural biopsies and talc pleurodesis for malignant pleural effusion. Continue chest tube suction with daily CXRs and drainage monitoring; consider tunneled pleural catheter if trapped lung persists.
registry_entry.primary_indication: Recurrent right malignant pleural effusion requiring definitive pleurodesis
registry_entry.radiographic_findings: Large right pleural effusion with compressive atelectasis and probable trapped lung
registry_entry.ventilation_mode: Single-lung ventilation during thoracoscopy, then two-lung ventilation
registry_entry.pleural_thoracoscopy_findings: Diffuse parietal pleural nodularity with partially trapped lung
registry_entry.bronch_specimen_tests: Pleural biopsies for histology and immunohistochemistry; pleural fluid cytology
registry_entry.final_diagnosis_prelim: Malignant pleural disease in setting of metastatic lung cancer
registry_entry.follow_up_plan: Daily CXR and chest tube output monitoring; consider tunneled pleural catheter if lung remains trapped or drainage persists

lines.selection_reason: Medical thoracoscopy with pleural biopsies and talc poudrage pleurodesis for malignant effusion.
note_spans: Four grams of sterile talc were insufflated evenly over the parietal pleural surfaces to perform talc poudrage pleurodesis.

per_code.notes: Thoracoscopic pleurodesis for malignant effusion; values from 2025 pleural fee schedule.

financial_analysis.notes: Single 32650 reported; thoracentesis and chest tube are inherent to thoracoscopic pleurodesis and not separately coded.

bullets: Operative description includes thoracoscopy, pleural biopsies, and talc poudrage pleurodesis with chest tube left in place.
Under current guidance, thoracentesis and chest tube placement are bundled into thoracoscopic pleurodesis, so 32650 alone is appropriate.

lines.selection_reason: Medical thoracoscopy with talc pleurodesis for malignant pleural effusion.
note_spans: Talc poudrage pleurodesis was performed throughout the right pleural cavity at the time of medical thoracoscopy.

per_code.notes: Thoracoscopic pleurodesis RVUs and payment per 2025 pleural fee schedule.

financial_analysis.notes: No separate thoracentesis or chest tube CPT modeled because they are bundled into 32650.

bullets: Thoracoscopic talc pleurodesis with pleural biopsies meets criteria for 32650.
Standalone thoracentesis or chest tube codes would duplicate work included in thoracoscopic pleurodesis.

note_text:
Interventional Pulmonology Procedure Note
Procedure: Medical thoracoscopy with talc pleurodesis and tunneled pleural catheter placement (right hemithorax)
Patient: Maria Alvarez, 71-year-old female with metastatic breast cancer and recurrent right malignant pleural effusion with trapped lung.
Anesthesia: General anesthesia with single-lumen endotracheal tube.
Indication: Rapidly recurrent symptomatic malignant pleural effusion with incomplete lung expansion after prior thoracenteses.

PROCEDURE IN DETAIL:
The patient was brought to the operating room, placed in the left lateral decubitus position, and intubated with a 7.5 endotracheal tube. General anesthesia was induced and maintained with inhaled agents and IV opioids. Single-lung ventilation of the left lung was used during the thoracoscopic portion.
Ultrasound identified a moderate right pleural effusion and a safe entry site in the 6th intercostal space at the midaxillary line. After sterile prep and local anesthetic, a trocar was inserted with return of serosanguinous fluid. Approximately 2000 mL were drained.
Thoracoscopic inspection showed diffuse parietal pleural tumor implants and a trapped right lower lobe. Multiple biopsies of parietal pleura were obtained. Four grams of sterile talc were insufflated evenly for poudrage pleurodesis. Because of trapped lung and anticipated ongoing fluid production, a tunneled indwelling pleural catheter was placed through a separate anterior chest wall tunnel and exited at the right anterior axillary line. The catheter was secured, connected to suction, and then capped.

COMPLICATIONS: None.
ESTIMATED BLOOD LOSS: ~25 mL
DISPOSITION: Discharged to home later the same day with tunneled pleural catheter in place and home health arranged for drainage.
IMPRESSION/PLAN: Medical thoracoscopy with pleural biopsies, talc pleurodesis, and tunneled pleural catheter placement for recurrent malignant effusion with trapped lung. Initiate home drainage three times weekly, adjust based on output. Oncology follow-up as scheduled.

registry_entry.note_text:
Interventional Pulmonology Procedure Note
Procedure: Medical thoracoscopy with talc pleurodesis and tunneled pleural catheter placement (right hemithorax)
Patient: Maria Alvarez, 71-year-old female with metastatic breast cancer and recurrent right malignant pleural effusion with trapped lung.
Anesthesia: General anesthesia with single-lumen endotracheal tube.
Indication: Rapidly recurrent symptomatic malignant pleural effusion with incomplete lung expansion after prior thoracenteses.

PROCEDURE IN DETAIL:
The patient was brought to the operating room, placed in the left lateral decubitus position, and intubated with a 7.5 endotracheal tube. General anesthesia was induced and maintained with inhaled agents and IV opioids. Single-lung ventilation of the left lung was used during the thoracoscopic portion.
Ultrasound identified a moderate right pleural effusion and a safe entry site in the 6th intercostal space at the midaxillary line. After sterile prep and local anesthetic, a trocar was inserted with return of serosanguinous fluid. Approximately 2000 mL were drained.
Thoracoscopic inspection showed diffuse parietal pleural tumor implants and a trapped right lower lobe. Multiple biopsies of parietal pleura were obtained. Four grams of sterile talc were insufflated evenly for poudrage pleurodesis. Because of trapped lung and anticipated ongoing fluid production, a tunneled indwelling pleural catheter was placed through a separate anterior chest wall tunnel and exited at the right anterior axillary line. The catheter was secured, connected to suction, and then capped.

COMPLICATIONS: None.
ESTIMATED BLOOD LOSS: ~25 mL
DISPOSITION: Discharged to home later the same day with tunneled pleural catheter in place and home health arranged for drainage.
IMPRESSION/PLAN: Medical thoracoscopy with pleural biopsies, talc pleurodesis, and tunneled pleural catheter placement for recurrent malignant effusion with trapped lung. Initiate home drainage three times weekly, adjust based on output. Oncology follow-up as scheduled.
registry_entry.primary_indication: Recurrent right malignant pleural effusion with trapped lung requiring thoracoscopy, pleurodesis, and tunneled pleural catheter
registry_entry.radiographic_findings: Right pleural effusion with underlying trapped lung and pleural nodularity on CT
registry_entry.ventilation_mode: Single-lung ventilation during thoracoscopy, then two-lung ventilation
registry_entry.pleural_procedure_type: Medical thoracoscopy with tunneled pleural catheter
registry_entry.pleural_thoracoscopy_findings: Multiple parietal pleural tumor implants with trapped lung
registry_entry.bronch_specimen_tests: Pleural biopsies for histology and receptor testing; pleural fluid for cytology
registry_entry.final_diagnosis_prelim: Malignant pleural disease in metastatic breast cancer
registry_entry.follow_up_plan: Home pleural catheter drainage three times weekly with visiting nurse support; oncology and IP clinic follow-up in 2 weeks

lines.selection_reason: Medical thoracoscopy with talc poudrage pleurodesis for malignant pleural effusion.
note_spans: Four grams of sterile talc were insufflated evenly over the parietal pleural surfaces for poudrage pleurodesis.

lines.description: Insertion of indwelling tunneled pleural catheter with cuff
lines.selection_reason: Separate tunneled indwelling pleural catheter was placed via a subcutaneous tunnel for ongoing outpatient drainage.
note_spans: A tunneled indwelling pleural catheter was placed through a separate anterior chest wall tunnel and secured for home drainage.

per_code.notes: Thoracoscopic pleurodesis primary code per 2025 pleural fee schedule.

per_code.description: Insertion of indwelling tunneled pleural catheter with cuff
per_code.notes: Tunneled pleural catheter insertion performed in the same session; separately reportable with thoracoscopic pleurodesis.

financial_analysis.notes: Totals reflect combined 32650 and 32550; NCCI guidance does not bundle tunneled pleural catheter placement into thoracoscopic pleurodesis.

bullets: Operative note documents thoracoscopy with talc pleurodesis and separate tunneled pleural catheter placement.
Under current NCCI edits, tunneled catheter insertion (32550) is not bundled into thoracoscopic pleurodesis (32650), so both codes are appropriate.

lines.selection_reason: Medical thoracoscopy with talc poudrage pleurodesis for malignant effusion.
note_spans: Talc poudrage pleurodesis was performed after thoracoscopic inspection and biopsies.

lines.description: Insertion of indwelling tunneled pleural catheter with cuff
lines.selection_reason: Indwelling tunneled pleural catheter was placed for outpatient drainage in the same session.
note_spans: A tunneled pleural catheter was placed via a subcutaneous tunnel and left in place for long-term drainage.

per_code.notes: Thoracoscopic pleurodesis values from the 2025 pleural fee schedule.

per_code.description: Insertion of indwelling tunneled pleural catheter with cuff
per_code.notes: Tunneled pleural catheter insertion values from the 2025 pleural fee schedule.

financial_analysis.notes: Combined professional RVUs and payments for 32650 and 32550 in a single session.

bullets: Thoracoscopy with talc pleurodesis and tunneled pleural catheter insertion are both explicitly documented.
Bundling rules in the 2025 pleural coding guidance allow separate reporting of 32550 with thoracoscopic pleurodesis (32650).
